I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2010 country programming mission, the Government of the People's Republic 
of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance 
(TA) to support reforms in fiscal policy, taxation, and budget management. The PRC country 
partnership  strategy,  2008–2010  under  the  pillar  "inclusive  growth  and  development," 
emphasizes  support  for  fiscal  reforms  to  strengthen  central  and  provincial  government 
resources and to promote the development of poor interior provinces.1 A TA fact-finding mission 
held detailed discussions on 6–9 April 2010 with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the State 
Administration of Taxation on the TA objectives, scope, implementation arrangements, costs, 
and terms of reference. This report reflects ADB's findings and understandings reached with the 
government on the TA. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.2    
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Taxation Reform 
2.  Tax structure. The PRC tax structure differs in some important aspects from that of 
member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). 
The share of indirect taxes in government revenue is 43%, significantly above the OECD 
average. Company taxation produces a yield similar to that in OECD countries, but personal 
income tax and social security contributions are of much less importance. Tax bases for value-
added and excise taxes are small compared with international good practice. Despite progress 
on curbing extrabudgetary funds,3 all levels of government continue to raise large amounts of 
funds  in  nontransparent  ways  outside  the  regular  budget  process.  Off-budget  government 
revenue remains large and unreported.  
 
3.  Formal  revenue  system.  Since  economic  reforms  began  in  1978,  the  budgetary 
revenue proportion of gross domestic product declined from 31.2% in 1978 to 10.7% in 1995, 
and then increased to 20.0% in 2008. The formal government tax revenue system remains 
relatively weak compared with international standards, and boundaries between the government 
and nongovernment sector are neither well defined nor stable. 
 
4.  Tax  system  and  macroeconomic  development.  Tax  reform  is  critical  to  support 
sustainable macroeconomic, social, and environmental development. The comparatively low 
level of core public services in the PRC, particularly for education, health, and social security, 
are  often  considered  to  be  a  major  reason  for  the  high  household  saving  rate.  As  a 
consequence, growth of the PRC economy has largely been driven by exports and investment, 
rather than consumption. Implementing policies to lower precautionary savings (i.e., reforming 
health,  education,  and  pension  systems,  which  may  require  additional  tax  revenue)  could 
increase private consumption and support growth in a sustainable manner. 
 
5.  Intergovernmental tax-sharing. The PRC is a decentralized country, consisting of five 
levels of government: national, provincial, city, county, and township. The 1994 tax reform 
introduced  tax-sharing  to  shift  revenue  collection  from  a  negotiated  basis  to  a  formal  tax 
assignment and sharing system between the central and provincial governments. Revenue 
assignments for local governments through the tax-sharing system are not properly linked to

spending  mandates.  Tax  authority  remains  vested  with  the  central  government;  local 
governments have limited powers to set rates for a few local taxes. Transfers from the central to 
the  local  governments  are  sizable,  but  do  not  provide  sufficient  financial  support  for  the 
provision of essential public services. Marked differences in revenue-generating capacity across 
provinces and lower levels of government have increased regional inequality. In combination 
with lack of tax autonomy, they have created incentives for local authorities to rely on extra- and 
off-budget  sources  for  revenue,  accumulate  arrears,  and  circumvent  official  borrowing 
restrictions by indirectly borrowing through investment vehicles. 
 
6.  Reform of the tax system in line with international best practice, including modernizing 
the tax structure, tax administration, and in particular intergovernment tax sharing, is critical to 
adapt the economy to the changing role of government and evolving external environment, 
ensure effective resource mobilization, achieve high sustainable growth, and equalize regional 
income disparities. 
 
B.  Financial Policy to support the Sustainable Development of Resource-Based 
Cities and Enterprises 
7.  The PRC faces serious environmental challenges, including pollution and depletion of 
natural resources. Resource-based cities4 are particularly exposed to environmental pollution, 
low diversification, vulnerability to shocks, resource depletion, and occupational accidents and 
diseases. While extractive industries can create significant opportunities for economic growth 
and  public  sector  revenue,  they  often  impede  sustainable  development  through  adverse 
environmental  and  socioeconomic  impacts,  and  encouragement  of  dependence  on  the 
generated revenues. Local governments often lack resources to provide basic public goods 
such as environmental protection and social services; additional resource revenue collection 
and management mechanisms need to be established. 
 
8.  The Sustainable Development Reserve and Fund (SDRF) policy, recently approved by 
the State Council, will collect revenue through a levy on enterprises in extractive industries. Part 
of the revenue will be retained in the enterprises as reserve to address the negative effects of 
mining,  the  remainder  will  be  allocated  as  earmarked  transfers  to  the  budget  of  local 
governments of resource-based cities. MOF is responsible for implementation of the SDRF 
policy. Based on clearly defined policy objectives, the funds will be used for environmentally and 
economically sustainable investments.  
 
C.  Treasury Management and Budget Execution Monitoring 
9.  Treasury reform is the primary focus of activities to improve the government's ability to 
control  and  monitor  budget  implementation.  In  2001,  MOF  initiated  this  reform  with  the 
introduction of the treasury single account (TSA).5 TSA implementation, in combination with an 
automated  treasury  accounting  system,  provides  information  needed  by  MOF  to  increase 
effective real-time monitoring and control of expenditure, and better enforce compliance with 
budget execution. The provinces are starting to set up TSAs, but substantial weaknesses 
remain for subnational and, in particular, subprovincial governments. 
                                                
4  The term "resource-based" is used here to cover cities and enterprises that derive a substantial part of production 
and income from natural resource extraction. The principal focus is on production of hydrocarbon (oil and gas) and 
mining. According to MOF statistics, the PRC has 118 resource-based cities, i.e., 18% of cities in the country. With 
two-thirds of mines entering middle and old age, one-fourth of resource-based cities are facing resource depletion. 
5  A standard TSA is a bank account or a set of linked bank accounts under the supervision and control of the 
Treasury Department through which the government (including its entities and spending units) transacts all receipts 
and payments, and consolidates its cash balances.

3 
 
10.  The greatest challenge for budget management in the PRC is the high degree of fiscal 
decentralization;  the  four  subnational  governments  account  for  80%  of  government 
expenditures, with the third and fourth tiers accounting for the greatest share. The five levels of 
administration comprise more than 44,000 government units. The central government finances 
about half of local expenditures through intergovernment transfers. Special purpose grants6 
represent the majority of transfers, excluding tax rebates, and reflect the central government’s 
proactive regional policy. They also challenge transparency of the system. 
 
11.  Real-time monitoring of budget execution by the Treasury Department is currently limited 
to  expenditure  by  the  central  government,  which  has  adopted  the  TSA  system,  while  the 
Treasury Department lacks the instruments to track in real-time the flow of funds through the 
multiple accounts of various tiers of local governments to the final beneficiaries. Allocated 
resources do not necessarily reach the intended recipients.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The impact will be strengthened fiscal policy, taxation, and budget management in the 
PRC. The outcome will be the design of an improved fiscal, taxation, and budget management 
framework. Related interventions by other development partners include a study by the United 
Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) on monitoring earmarked fiscal transfers from the central to 
local governments for education and rural health care. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA comprises three components: (i) a study on further deepening tax system reform, 
(ii) a framework for financial policy to support sustainable development of resource-based cities 
and enterprises, and (iii) support for implementation of the TSA and a real-time monitoring 
system  for  budget  execution.  Studies  of  the  components  will  be  published  as  knowledge 
products—policy and technical notes for researchers and senior policy and decision makers. 
 
14.  Study  on  further  deepening  tax  system  reform.  The  TA  will  build  on  previous 
research and prepare an in-depth study of the tax system and general principles for mid- and 
long-term tax reform, including reports on: 
(i)  rationalizing  the  tax  structure  in  line  with  good  international  practice  by 
broadening the tax base, simplifying tax structure, extending budget coverage to 
extrabudgetary  revenue,  simplifying  and  keeping  down  the  costs  of  tax 
administration and compliance, and increasing transparency; 
(ii)  determining the optimal formal tax revenue proportion of gross domestic product; 
(iii)  the  interaction  between  tax  system  reform  and  sustainable  macroeconomic 
development; and  
(iv)  reform  of  the  intergovernment  tax-sharing  system  by  (a)  establishing  a 
transparent framework for effective, efficient, and equitable tax revenue sharing 
between the central and local governments; (b) providing local authorities with 
sufficient  resources  to  fund  required  public  services;  (c) developing  a  new, 
revenue-rich  local  government  tax;  and  (d)  exploring  options  to  extend  the 
powers of local government to levy taxes. 
  
                                                
6  Specific-purpose grants are designated transfers allocated on an ad hoc negotiated basis.

4   
15.  Particular emphasis will be placed on reform of the intergovernment tax-sharing system. 
The study will guide tax reform under the 12th Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. 
 
16.  Framework for financial policy to support sustainable development of resource-
based  cities. The  scope for  using taxes,  levies,  and fees  to  increase  the  contribution of 
enterprises  in  extractive  industries  to  poverty  reduction  and  sustainable  development  is 
significant.  Structural  weaknesses  in  the  current  tax  system,  intergovernmental  tax-sharing 
system,  and  tax  administration  require  the  creation  of  special  resource  revenue  and 
management  mechanisms  to  provide  timely  and  adequate  support  for  the  sustainable 
development of resource-based cities, in addition to relying on the regular budget process.  
 
17.  Based on extensive previous research by MOF’s Enterprise Department, the TA will 
develop the foundation for a framework for the SDRF policy based on international experience, 
draft implementing regulations, and explore opportunities to coordinate the SDRF policy with 
strengthened environmental taxation within the framework of general tax reform through close 
cooperation  with  component  1.  The  main  building  blocks  of  the  SDRF  policy  include  the 
institutional  and  governance  structure  of  the  resource  revenue  and  management  systems; 
design of an appropriate system of levies (including levy base and rates); allocation of revenue 
between eligible beneficiaries and projects; and establishment of an effective operations and 
financial monitoring, evaluation, and audit system. 
 
18.  Support for implementation of a real-time monitoring system for budget execution. 
The  TA  will  support  the  implementation  of  the  TSA,  including  optimal  intergovernmental 
integration,  and  a  nationwide  real-time  budget  monitoring  system,  in  particular  for  special 
purpose grants from the central to subnational governments, and provide training to central and 
local government officials.  
 
19.  The TA will prepare an in-depth study on implementing a real-time monitoring system for 
budget execution, consisting of three reports:  
(i)  The first report will analyze the current status of (a) implementation of the TSA 
and central treasury accounting system for subnational governments, including 
integration  with  the  central  government,  (b)  real-time  monitoring  of  budget 
execution for all levels of government, (c) legal basis for the central government 
treasury  function  and  budget  monitoring  of  subnational  governments,  and  
(d) subnational government reporting and disclosure of budget execution. The 
report will provide an overview of relevant concepts in line with international good 
practice.  
(ii)  The  second  report  will  (a)  develop  the  required  design  and  capacity  of  a 
countrywide  information  technology  management  information  system  for 
payments  and  possibly  transactions  at  all  stages  of  the  expenditure  cycle, 
supporting  implementation  of  the  TSA  and  real-time  monitoring  of  budget 
execution; (b) assess appropriate electronic connections between the People's 
Bank of China, MOF, line ministries, local treasury offices, and spending units, 
considering weak communication links to some parts of country; and (c) identify 
training needs in implementing management information systems.  
(iii)  The third report will develop the framework for the complete implementation and 
optimal integration of the TSA and for a real-time budget monitoring system at all 
levels of government. The report will develop (a) a strategy for implementing real-
time  monitoring  of  budget  execution  at  all  government  levels;  
(b)  an  implementation  plan  including  computerization;  (c) requirements  for 
integrated payment and accounting systems; (d) a comprehensive, reliable, and

5 
timely fiscal reporting system for improved transparency; and (e) an assessment 
of capacity building needs of local governments.  
 
20.  The TA will closely cooperate with the ADB TA for Supporting Fiscal Reforms in High 
Priority  Sectors,  which  is  providing  support for  designing  local treasury  cash management 
systems.7 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
21.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,400,000 equivalent, of which $1,200,000 equivalent will 
be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF—others). The 
government  will  provide  the  equivalent  of  $200,000  through  the  provision  of  office 
accommodation, transport, remuneration, and per diem of counterpart staff (Appendix 2). 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  MOF’s  International  Department  will  be  the  executing  agency.  The  implementing 
agencies  will  be  (i)  for  the  first  component:  the  Policy  and  Law  Department  of  the  State 
Administration of Taxation and MOF’s Tax Policy Department; (ii) for the second component: 
MOF’s Enterprise Department; and (iii) for the third component: MOF’s Treasury Department. 
Senior advisory committees comprising ministerial and department representatives will provide 
supervision. The TA will engage a team of three international consultants to provide 7 person-
months of services and 14 national experts to provide 66 person-months of services. Activities 
are expected to commence in August 2010; the project will be closed in December 2012. 
 
23.  MOF’s International Department, in consultation with the implementing agencies and 
with ADB support, will be responsible for administering national training programs, seminars, 
international  workshops,  in-country  study  visits,  and  international  study  tours.  Due  to  the 
diversity of the three components, a single firm cannot provide well-qualified consultants for the 
entire project. Component 1 will recruit a firm to provide national consultants. The smaller 
components 2 and 3 will recruit individual consultants. If no appropriate firm(s) can be identified 
for component 1 the consultants will be recruited on an individual basis. For recruitment of a firm, 
the  preferred  selection  method  for  consultants  is  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  with  a 
quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The international consultants will be recruited on an individual basis. 
The TA  consultants  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA proceeds will be disbursed in 
accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,200,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for Supporting Reforms in Taxation and 
Budget Management, and hereby reports such action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Component 1: Study on Further Deepening Tax System Reform 
1.  International  taxation  specialist (4.5 person-months). The specialist must have at 
least 15 years experience as a researcher in taxation either at a reputable university or research 
institute. The specialist will have strong expertise and experience in (i) general principles for 
mid- and long-term tax reforms, (ii) international trends in taxation reform in theory and practice, 
(iii) tax system reform and sustainable macroeconomic development, (iv) intergovernment tax-
sharing systems, (v) efficient tax structure, and (vi) environment taxation. The specialist should 
have substantial professional experience and knowledge of the tax system and public sector 
management in the People's Republic of China (PRC). The specialist will: 
(i)  provide  advice  to  the  advisory  commission  on  research  topics,  in  particular 
related to international trends in taxation theory and practice; 
(ii)  support the establishment of research groups and selection of qualified national 
consultants; 
(iii)  provide continuous advice to national taxation specialists and research groups on 
research topics, materials, and tools, including relevant literature; 
(iv)  adapt lessons of international trends in taxation theory and practice to specific 
PRC conditions; 
(v)  support arrangement of local and international conferences by drafting agendas, 
proposing participants, and providing keynote speeches;  
(vi)  support  arrangement  of  an  international  study  tour  for  relevant  government 
officials by proposing study areas, host countries, and institutions; 
(vii)  contribute directly to preparation of subreports and overall study; and 
(viii)  provide a final review of subreports, overall study, and knowledge products. 
 
2.  National taxation specialists (five specialists, 25 person-months total). The specialists 
will head the research groups for the overall study and subreports and contribute, in cooperation 
with staff from the State Administration of Taxation and the Ministry of Finance (MOF), to 
preparation  of  the  studies  by  providing  guidance  and  advice.  Research  groups  will  be 
established for the overall study and each subreport, supported by the international taxation 
specialist, and work for the full-time equivalent of 5 months.  
 
3.  The specialists will be either experienced researchers from reputable universities or 
research institutes and/or have a background as professionals from public authorities. The 
specialists should have expertise in (i) general principles for mid- and long-term tax reforms, 
(ii) international trends in taxation reform in theory and practice, (iii) tax system reform and 
sustainable macroeconomic development, (iv) tax-sharing systems between central and local 
governments, (v) rationalization of tax structure, and (vi) environment taxation. One of the 
specialists will be appointed team leader. The team leader, in cooperation with the international
